speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the specific attention issues you've been experiencing? How long have these changes in behavior been noticeable?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been having a hard time focusing in class, and it feels like my mind just wanders. My mom says it's been going on since I started high school, but I didn't really notice it until recently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your sleep patterns or energy levels during this time?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in my sleep patterns or energy levels. I feel pretty much the same in that regard.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any significant changes in your mood, such as increased irritability or feelings of sadness?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been feeling more irritable, especially towards my mom. I just get frustrated easily, but I don't really feel sad most of the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent changes in your diet or weight, or have you been under any unusual stress at school or home?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't changed my diet or noticed any weight changes. School has been a bit stressful with all the new subjects, but I think it's mostly just feeling overwhelmed.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any difficulties with memory or recalling information, especially related to schoolwork?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, sometimes I struggle to remember things I studied for tests or even what the teacher just explained. It feels like I can't keep everything straight in my head.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any physical symptoms, such as headaches, stomachaches, or any other discomfort that might be affecting your concentration?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any physical symptoms like headaches or stomachaches. It's really just the concentration issues that are bothering me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any episodes of hyperactivity or impulsivity, such as acting without thinking or having trouble sitting still?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've had any hyperactivity or impulsivity. I usually just feel restless and find it hard to stay engaged, but I don't act out or anything like that.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your social interactions or relationships with friends since these attention issues began?

speaker: Patient
text: I've definitely been withdrawing from my friends. I used to enjoy hanging out with my cheerleading squad, but now I just don't feel like doing those things anymore.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any significant life changes or events recently that might have contributed to these feelings of withdrawal or changes in behavior?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any major life changes recently, but starting high school has been a big adjustment for me. I think it's just been overwhelming, and I feel like I don't fit in as well as I used to.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with any mental health conditions in the past, or have you received any counseling or therapy for your feelings or behavior?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been diagnosed with any mental health conditions before, and I haven't had any counseling or therapy. I guess I just thought I could handle it on my own.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your ability to complete tasks or assignments, such as procrastination or difficulty following through on projects?

speaker: Patient
text: I've definitely been procrastinating more than usual. I start assignments but struggle to finish them on time, and I often feel overwhelmed by the amount of work.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any issues with organization, such as losing track of assignments or forgetting to bring necessary materials to school?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've been losing track of assignments a lot lately. Sometimes I forget to bring my books or materials to class, and it makes things even harder for me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any patterns in your attention issues, such as specific times of day when they are worse, or particular subjects that are more challenging for you?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that my attention issues are worse in the morning, especially during math class. I find it really hard to concentrate when the material gets complicated.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any feelings of anxiety or nervousness, particularly in academic settings or during tests?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really feel anxious or nervous during tests, but I do get a bit overwhelmed with all the new material. It's more like I just can't focus rather than feeling anxious about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any family history of attention issues, learning disabilities, or mental health conditions that might be relevant?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know much about my family's history, but my mom has mentioned that my uncle had some trouble with attention when he was younger. Other than that, I haven't heard of any specific issues.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your physical activity levels or hobbies that you used to enjoy?

speaker: Patient
text: I used to love hanging out with my cheerleading squad and going to practice, but now I just don't feel like doing it anymore. I find myself avoiding those activities and spending more time alone.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your ability to enjoy activities you once loved, or do you feel more apathetic towards things that used to excite you?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I definitely feel more apathetic. I used to get excited about cheerleading and hanging out with my friends, but now it just feels like too much effort, and I don't really care about it anymore.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're experiencing a significant shift in your interests and motivation. Have you had any thoughts about self-harm or feelings of worthlessness during this time?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any thoughts about self-harm or feelings of worthlessness. I just feel overwhelmed and disconnected from things I used to enjoy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your ability to concentrate during activities outside of school, such as reading for pleasure or watching movies?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that I have a hard time concentrating even when I'm trying to read for fun or watch a movie. I often find myself zoning out and not really paying attention to what's happening.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're experiencing difficulties with concentration across various aspects of your life, which is concerning. Based on the information you've provided, I believe I have enough to make a diagnosis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), predominantly inattentive presentation.

speaker: Patient
text: I appreciate you taking the time to listen to me. I just want to understand what's going on and how I can feel better. What are the next steps?

speaker: Doctor
text: Maximum inferences reached

speaker: Patient
text: I'm really hoping to find some strategies to help me focus better and manage my schoolwork. What can I do to improve my situation?
